title: Introduction
body: Much of government best practice in quality assurance is the result of a lesson learnt in 2012. The Department for Transport found errors in the procurement process of the InterCity West Coast franchise, which ultimately cost taxpayers at least £50 million. According to the PAC report, mistakes in the risk capital calculations opened the process to risk of legal challenge and ultimately led to the cancellation of the franchise competition.
instruction: {{_globals._learnerInfo.firstname}}, scroll down to see what came next!

title: Text
body:
Placeholder Text
Words from Phillip Rutland
  • History of west coast mainline;
  • the context
  • the challenges the reaction and civil service response

title: Narrative
body: In October 2012, the Cabinet Secretary and the Head of the Civil Service commissioned a review of the quality assurance (QA) of analytical models that inform government policy.
instruction: Select the next and back arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the next and back arrows followed by the plus icon to find out more.

_items.title: Commission started
_items.body: Since the difficulties with the Intercity West Coast franchise competition, the quality of government analysis has, rightly, been scrutinised. In October 2012, Nick Macpherson was commissioned to review the quality assurance of analytical models across government.

_items.title: Review of quality assurance of Government analytical models
_items.body: The recommendations of that review were written with the aim to extend best practice across the whole of government. They focus on quality assurance, governance and accountability, culture, capacity, capability and control.

_items.title: Aftermath
_items.body: Macpherson review (words from ex perm sec, perhaps on the review the context in 2013 of building trust, how government came together and established a set of principles that would be relevant to everyone for years to come)

title: Multiple Choice Question
body: What modelling error lead to the MacPherson review
instruction: Choose one or more options and select Submit.

_items.text: Aquatrine Package B PFI Financial Model

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: That’s correct. In 2012 the UK government ran a competition for who would run a particular service (the InterCity West Coast rail franchise). Civil servants modelled the various bids to assess its costs and benefits and a winner of the competition announced as a result. Unfortunately for the government, this decision was challenged in the courts and it turned out that there were mistakes in the modelling, and the decision was retracted. This caused the government some embarrassment as well as cost it quite a bit of money because it had to re-run the competition.

_incorrect.final: That’s not right. It was actually the the InterCity West Coast rail franchise

title: Graphical Multiple Choice Question
body: There are many causes of modelling error. Which of these was not identified as a cause of modelling error?
instruction: Choose an option and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
That’s correct.
parsimonious models is what we were looking for!

title: Slider
body: How many recommendations did Macpheron make to improve modelling?
instruction: Drag the slider to make your choice and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Yes, that’s right.
Its eight recommendations focussed around creating the right environment, establishing clear processes and publicly reporting this. They aim to extend best practice across the whole of government.

_incorrect.final: Sorry, that’s not right, there are 8 Recommendations. The 8 recommendations aim to support departments by setting out the key elements needed for good environment and process. The review recommended departments and their ALBs should develop plans for both the elements in a way that fits with their remit, and is proportionate to risk. The inputs specified  are not exhaustive, but rather give a minimum guideline as to what organisations should address in QA plans going forward.
